bioghist.p: John C. Wister (1887-1982) was a landscape architect. He graduated from Harvard University and studied at the Harvard School of Landscape Architecture and the New Jersey Agricultural College. He served in Europe during World War I, and in his spare time visited gardens and leading horticulturists. He was one of the founders and the first president of the American Iris Society, and served as secretary of the American Rose Society for many years. He belonged to many other horticultural, scientific, and conservation organizations. He was the first director of the Arthur Hoyt Horticultural Foundation, and designed and created the 240-acre public garden at Swarthmore College. He was the author of four books: The Iris, Lilac Culture, Bulbs for American Gardens, and Four Seasons in Your Garden.

scopecontent.p: The John Wister slide collection comprises two series of color lantern slides: The Gardeners, photographs of suburban Philadelphia gardens, identified by name of property owners; and a general collection that includes views of gardens, sights, and specific plants from Europe and the U.S. There are 35mm slide reproductions of many of the lantern slides in the collection.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
